lines.name: Ginza Line
lines.description: The Ginza Line is the oldest subway line in Asia, opened in 1927. It connects Shibuya in the west to Asakusa in the east, passing through the famous Ginza shopping district.

lines.name: Marunouchi Line
lines.description: The Marunouchi Line is a U-shaped line connecting Ogikubo in the west to Ikebukuro in the north, passing through central Tokyo including Shinjuku and Tokyo Station. It includes a branch to Honancho.

lines.name: Hibiya Line
lines.description: The Hibiya Line connects Naka-Meguro to Kita-Senju, serving the Roppongi entertainment district and connecting to Tobu Railway for through services to Saitama.

lines.name: Tozai Line
lines.description: The Tozai Line is the busiest subway line in Japan, connecting Nakano to Nishi-Funabashi in Chiba Prefecture. It suffers from extreme crowding during rush hours, reaching over 180% capacity.

lines.name: Chiyoda Line
lines.description: The Chiyoda Line connects Yoyogi-Uehara to Kita-Ayase, serving government buildings in Kasumigaseki and connecting to Odakyu and JR Joban lines for through services.

lines.name: Yurakucho Line
lines.description: The Yurakucho Line connects Wakoshi in Saitama to Shin-Kiba on Tokyo Bay, serving Ikebukuro and the Yurakucho business district. It shares tracks with Tobu Tojo and Seibu Ikebukuro lines.

lines.name: Hanzomon Line
lines.description: The Hanzomon Line connects Shibuya to Oshiage (Tokyo Skytree), with through services to Tokyu Den-en-toshi Line and Tobu Skytree Line, creating a long cross-city route.

lines.name: Namboku Line
lines.description: The Namboku Line connects Meguro to Akabane-Iwabuchi, featuring platform screen doors at all stations for safety. It connects to Tokyu Meguro Line and Saitama Railway.

lines.name: Fukutoshin Line
lines.description: The Fukutoshin Line is the newest Tokyo Metro line, connecting Wakoshi to Shibuya via Ikebukuro and Shinjuku. It provides through services to Tobu Tojo, Seibu Ikebukuro, and Tokyu Toyoko lines.
